publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Bezeklikduring T III M 135.3

sourceDesc.p: Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).
Transcription and translation are based on .

p.note: Striking is s for ts in a5 oktasi and b1 kāse.
In this text, the Tocharian A translations seem to follow after each complete Sanskrit strophe (instead of each half pāda, as is often the case).

The reading of the leaf number is very uncertain. The first akṣara (there was probably no other one on top of this one) seems to be ‹60›, the second may be ‹7›, ‹8›, or ‹9›. If the reading of at least the ‹60› is correct, the manuscript will have contained another text preceding the Varṇārhavarṇastotra: with approximately 7 strophes per leaf, the beginning of the latter text may have to be placed about 35 leaves before this one.

śkaṃ tom kleśāñ tñi: parts of the translation of 7.11c-d na ceme granthayo 'nyatra cchidyante tvanmatād ṛte 'Diese Fesseln werden aber nirgends als in deiner Lehre zerschnitten.' (223). The syntax of the Tocharian A translation is different. 176 plausibly suggests to restore ā /// to ā(kṣiñluneyäṣ pkänt), which would give us something like '(Apart from) your teaching, these kleśas are (not cut off)'.

oko lyockäṣt: renders 7.12d tvayi sāphalyam āgataḥ (see line a3; pace 745) 'hat in dir ihre Erfüllung gefunden' (224). However, literally the Tocharian A seems to mean 'you have turned [it] into fruit' (taking a little more freedom, 176 translates 'liet de vrucht ontstaan', i.e. '[you] let the fruit arise'). täm(y)o 'therefore' seems to begin a next clause that has no precise Sanskrit parallel.

oktasi ytār nervāṃ 'the eightfold path, the nirvāṇa' may perhaps somehow, but certainly not literally, correspond to 7.13a pratipad brāhmī 'den Brahma zugehörigen Weg' (224). The literal correspondence of pratipad brāhmī is found in line b4.

cf. 7.14a-b na tvayā saṃskṛtaḥ kaś cid bhavati brāhmaṇo 'śuciḥ 'Nicht wird irgendein durch dich (rituell) gereinigter Brahmane (wieder rituell) unrein' (225). The variant reading (sa)dṛśa{ḥ} attested here is certain.

mā śkaṃ kāse klo: translates 7.14c na copanīto 'und nicht fällt ein (von dir) eingeführter' (225). kāse klo (for kātse klo) literally means 'led close' and is without doubt a calque (Skt. upa = TA kātse, Skt. nī- = TA kälā-.
(śpā)lmeṃ tre: last part of the translation 7.15d brāhmaṇapravarās trayaḥ 'die drei brahmanischen Ahnherren' (225).

mā brāmaṇi ytār kl(awanträ): renders 7.16b na brāhmī pratipat kva cit 'nirgendwo den brahmanischen Weg' (226). 177 restores to kl(yant naṣ) 'bevindt zich [niet]', i.e. 'is [not] there', but the relevant akṣara can only be kla or klā. With the restoration kl(awanträ), a literal translation of the Tocharian A text becomes: 'they do [not] call the Brahmanic path'.

(e)he kāsu kälko yruñci: renders the beginning of 7.17c (sugatāve)ṇikaivaiṣā 'gerade nur [dem Wohlgegangenen] eigentümlich ist' (227. There is no place for the equivalent of TA ehe 'oh' in the restored Skt. text. On yruñci, the equivalent of Skt. āveṇika 'independent; characteristic', see 177.

div.p: Edition217; 176-177. Siegling's personal copy of p. 217.

list.item: a1 grasto : brāhmaṇa kiṃ bha[v]i /// a2 śkaṃ to_m\ kleśāñä\ tñi ā /// a3 sāphalyam āgataḥ [10] /// a4 oko lyoc_k_a_ṣ_t\ _t_a[m](·)o /// a5 oktasi ytār nervāṃ /// a6 dṛśa kaś cid bhava /// b1 [mā] śkaṃ kāse klo /// b2 pravarās trayaḥ [10] /// b3 lmeṃ tre 10-5 na ·[i] /// b4 mā brāmaṇi ytā_r\ kl· /// b5 loke sarvaṃ tat tava śā /// b6 he kāsu _k_alko yruñci ///
Striking is s for ts in a5 oktasi and b1 kāse.

[[IDP]]: THT 1026, [[THT|TITUS]]: THT 1026.
Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling, Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS). Transcription and translation are based on [[Carling, DThTA]].
Edition: [[TochSprR(A)]]: 217; [[Couvreur 1966]]: 176-177.
Siegling's personal copy of [[TochSprR(A)]]: p. 217.
Translation: a5 [[Knoll 1996]]: 128; b6 [[Knoll 1996]]: 141.

In this text, the Tocharian A translations seem to follow after each complete Sanskrit strophe (instead of each half pāda, as is often the case).

a1. 7.11a-b

a2. śkaṃ tom kleśāñ tñi: parts of the translation of 7.11c-d na ceme granthayo 'nyatra cchidyante tvanmatād ṛte 'Diese Fesseln werden aber nirgends als in deiner Lehre zerschnitten.' ([[Hartmann JU 1987]]: 223). The syntax of the Tocharian A translation is different. [[Couvreur 1966]]: 176 plausibly suggests to restore ā /// to ā(kṣiñluneyäṣ pkänt), which would give us something like '(Apart from) your teaching, these kleśas are (not cut off)'.

a3. cf. 7.12d tvayi sāphalyam āgataḥ.

a4. oko lyockäṣt: renders 7.12d tvayi sāphalyam āgataḥ (see line a3; pace [[Peyrot, ToSu]]: 745) 'hat in dir ihre Erfüllung gefunden' ([[Hartmann JU 1987]]: 224). However, literally the Tocharian A seems to mean 'you have turned [it] into fruit' (taking a little more freedom, [[Couvreur 1966]]: 176 translates 'liet de vrucht ontstaan', i.e. '[you] let the fruit arise'). täm(y)o 'therefore' seems to begin a next clause that has no precise Sanskrit parallel.

a5. oktasi ytār nervāṃ 'the eightfold path, the nirvāṇa' may perhaps somehow, but certainly not literally, correspond to 7.13a pratipad brāhmī 'den Brahma zugehörigen Weg' ([[Hartmann JU 1987]]: 224). The literal correspondence of pratipad brāhmī is found in line b4.

a6. cf. 7.14a-b na tvayā saṃskṛtaḥ kaś cid bhavati brāhmaṇo 'śuciḥ 'Nicht wird irgendein durch dich (rituell) gereinigter Brahmane (wieder rituell) unrein' ([[Hartmann JU 1987]]: 225). The variant reading (sa)dṛśa{ḥ} attested here is certain.

b1. [mā]: can be read pace [[TochSprR(A)]]: 217.

b1. mā śkaṃ kāse klo: translates 7.14c na copanīto 'und nicht fällt ein (von dir) eingeführter' ([[Hartmann JU 1987]]: 225). kāse klo (for kātse klo) literally means 'led close' and is without doubt a calque (Skt. upa = TA kātse, Skt. nī- = TA kälā-.

b2. 7.15d.

b3. (śpā)lmeṃ tre: last part of the translation 7.15d brāhmaṇapravarās trayaḥ 'die drei brahmanischen Ahnherren' ([[Hartmann JU 1987]]: 225).

b3. na (h)i: beginning of Skt. 7.16a.

b4. mā brāmaṇi ytār kl(awanträ): renders 7.16b na brāhmī pratipat kva cit 'nirgendwo den brahmanischen Weg' ([[Hartmann JU 1987]]: 226). [[Couvreur 1966]]: 177 restores to kl(yant naṣ) 'bevindt zich [niet]', i.e. 'is [not] there', but the relevant akṣara can only be kla or klā. With the restoration kl(awanträ), a literal translation of the Tocharian A text becomes: 'they do [not] call the Brahmanic path'.

b5. The end of 7.17.a, and 7.17b.

b6. (e)he kāsu kälko yruñci: renders the beginning of 7.17c (sugatāve)ṇikaivaiṣā 'gerade nur [dem Wohlgegangenen] eigentümlich ist' ([[Hartmann JU 1987]]: 227. There is no place for the equivalent of TA ehe 'oh' in the restored Skt. text. On yruñci, the equivalent of Skt. āveṇika 'independent; characteristic', see [[Couvreur 1966]]: 177.

The reading of the leaf number is very uncertain. The first akṣara (there was probably no other one on top of this one) seems to be ‹60›, the second may be ‹7›, ‹8›, or ‹9›. If the reading of at least the ‹60› is correct, the manuscript will have contained another text preceding the Varṇārhavarṇastotra: with approximately 7 strophes per leaf, the beginning of the latter text may have to be placed about 35 leaves before this one.

kudṛṣṭivimatigrasto|(kudṛṣṭivimati)|grasto a1 : brāhmaṇa kiṃ bhavi(ṣyati) /// a2 śkaṃ tom kleśāñ tñi ā(kṣiñluneyäṣ) /// a3 sāphalyam āgataḥ 10(-2) /// a4 oko lyockäṣt täm(y)o /// a5 oktasi ytār nervāṃ /// sadṛśa|(sa)|dṛśa a6 kaś cid bhava(ti) /// b1 mā śkaṃ kāse klo /// brāhmaṇapravarās|(brāhmaṇa)|pravarās b2 trayaḥ 10(-5) /// śpālmeṃ_(TA)|(śpā)|lmeṃ b3 tre 15 na (h)i /// b4 mā brāmaṇi ytār kl(awanträ) /// b5 loke sarvaṃ tat tava śā(sanāt) /// ehe|(e)|he b6 kāsu kälko yruñci ///
